Authors: Sokolova E., Petterson S.R., Dienus O., Nystrom F., Lindgren P.-E., Pettersson T.J.R.
Title: Microbial risk assessment of drinking water based on hydrodynamic modelling of pathogen concentrations in source water
Affiliations: Chalmers University of Technology, Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Water Environment Technology, Gothenburg, Sweden; Norwegian University of Life Sciences NMBU, Department of Mathematical Sciences and Technology, P.O. Box 5003, Ås, Norway; Water and Health Pty Ltd, P.O. Box 648 Salamander Bay, Australia; Ryhov County Hospital, Medical Services, Clinical Microbiology, Jönköping, Sweden; Linköping University, Department of Clinical and Experimental Medicine, Medical Microbiology, Linköping, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Sokolova, E., Chalmers University of Technology, Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Water Environment Technology, Gothenburg, Sweden; Petterson, S.R., Norwegian University of Life Sciences NMBU, Department of Mathematical Sciences and Technology, P.O. Box 5003, Ås, Norway, Water and Health Pty Ltd, P.O. Box 648 Salamander Bay, Australia; Dienus, O., Ryhov County Hospital, Medical Services, Clinical Microbiology, Jönköping, Sweden; Nyström, F., Ryhov County Hospital, Medical Services, Clinical Microbiology, Jönköping, Sweden, Linköping University, Department of Clinical and Experimental Medicine, Medical Microbiology, Linköping, Sweden; Lindgren, P.-E., Ryhov County Hospital, Medical Services, Clinical Microbiology, Jönköping, Sweden, Linköping University, Department of Clinical and Experimental Medicine, Medical Microbiology, Linköping, Sweden; Pettersson, T.J.R., Chalmers University of Technology, Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Water Environment Technology, Gothenburg, Sweden
Abstract: Norovirus contamination of drinking water sources is an important cause of waterborne disease outbreaks. Knowledge on pathogen concentrations in source water is needed to assess the ability of a drinking water treatment plant (DWTP) to provide safe drinking water. However, pathogen enumeration in source water samples is often not sufficient to describe the source water quality. In this study, the norovirus concentrations were characterised at the contamination source, i.e. in sewage discharges. Then, the transport of norovirus within the water source (the river Göta älv in Sweden) under different loading conditions was simulated using a hydrodynamic model. Based on the estimated concentrations in source water, the required reduction of norovirus at the DWTP was calculated using quantitative microbial risk assessment (QMRA). The required reduction was compared with the estimated treatment performance at the DWTP. The average estimated concentration in source water varied between 4.8×102 and 7.5×103 genome equivalents L-1; and the average required reduction by treatment was between 7.6 and 8.8 Log<inf>10</inf>. The treatment performance at the DWTP was estimated to be adequate to deal with all tested loading conditions, but was heavily dependent on chlorine disinfection, with the risk of poor reduction by conventional treatment and slow sand filtration. To our knowledge, this is the first article to employ discharge-based QMRA, combined with hydrodynamic modelling, in the context of drinking water. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.
Author Keywords: Discharge-based QMRA; Norovirus; QMRA; Quantitative microbial risk assessment; Water quality modelling

Authors: Alves P.R.L., Natal-da-Luz T., Sousa J.P., Cardoso E.J.B.N.
Title: Ecotoxicological characterization of sugarcane vinasses when applied to tropical soils
Affiliations: Dep. of Soil Science, University of São Paulo, Pádua Dias Str 11, Piracicaba, Brazil; CAPES Foundation, Ministry of Education of Brazil, Brasília, Brazil; CFE, Dep. of Life Sciences, University of Coimbra, Calçada Martim de Freitas, Coimbra, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Alves, P.R.L., Dep. of Soil Science, University of São Paulo, Pádua Dias Str 11, Piracicaba, Brazil, CAPES Foundation, Ministry of Education of Brazil, Brasília, Brazil; Natal-da-Luz, T., CFE, Dep. of Life Sciences, University of Coimbra, Calçada Martim de Freitas, Coimbra, Portugal; Sousa, J.P., CFE, Dep. of Life Sciences, University of Coimbra, Calçada Martim de Freitas, Coimbra, Portugal; Cardoso, E.J.B.N., Dep. of Soil Science, University of São Paulo, Pádua Dias Str 11, Piracicaba, Brazil
Abstract: The impact of sugarcane vinasse on soil invertebrates was assessed through ecotoxicological assays. Increasing concentrations of two vinasses from different distillery plants (VA and VB), and a vinasse from a laboratory production (VC), were amended on two natural tropical Oxisols (LV and LVA) and a tropical artificial soil (TAS) to characterize the effects of the vinasses on earthworms (. Eisenia andrei), enchytraeids (. Enchytraeus crypticus), mites (. Hypoaspis aculeifer) and collembolans (. Folsomia candida). The highest concentrations of VA and VB were avoided by earthworms in all soils and by collembolans especially in the natural soils. The presence of VC in all of the tested soils did not cause avoidance behavior in these species. The reproduction of earthworms, enchytraeids and collembolans was decreased in the highest concentrations of VA and VB in the natural soils. In TAS, VB reduced the reproduction of all test species, whereas VA was toxic exclusively to E. andrei and E. crypticus. The vinasse VC only reduced the number of earthworms in TAS and enchytraeids in LVA. The reproduction of mites was reduced by VB in TAS. Vinasses from distillery plants were more toxic than the vinasse produced in laboratory. The vinasse toxicities were influenced by soil type, although this result was most likely because of the way the organisms are exposed to the contaminants in the soils. Toxicity was attributed to the vinasses' high salt content and especially the high potassium concentrations. Data obtained in this study highlights the potential risk of vinasse disposal on tropical soils to soil biota. The toxic values estimated are even more relevant when considering the usual continuous use of vinasses in crop productions. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.
Author Keywords: Arthropoda; Ecotoxicity; Oligochaeta; Oxisol; Soil invertebrates

Authors: Wu X., Sten P., Engblom S., Nowak P., Osterholm P., Dopson M.
Title: Impact of mitigation strategies on acid sulfate soil chemistry and microbial community
Affiliations: Centre for Ecology and Evolution in Microbial Model Systems (EEMiS), Linnaeus University, Kalmar, Sweden; Energy and Environmental Technology, Vaasa University of Applied Sciences, Vaasa, Finland; R and D Department, Novia University of Applied Sciences, Vaasa, Finland; Jerzy Haber Institute of Catalysis and Surface Chemistry, Polish Academy of Sciences, Kraków, Poland; Department of Geology and Mineralogy, Åbo Akademi University, Åbo, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Wu, X., Centre for Ecology and Evolution in Microbial Model Systems (EEMiS), Linnaeus University, Kalmar, Sweden; Sten, P., Energy and Environmental Technology, Vaasa University of Applied Sciences, Vaasa, Finland; Engblom, S., R and D Department, Novia University of Applied Sciences, Vaasa, Finland; Nowak, P., Jerzy Haber Institute of Catalysis and Surface Chemistry, Polish Academy of Sciences, Kraków, Poland; Österholm, P., Department of Geology and Mineralogy, Åbo Akademi University, Åbo, Finland; Dopson, M., Centre for Ecology and Evolution in Microbial Model Systems (EEMiS), Linnaeus University, Kalmar, Sweden
Abstract: Potential acid sulfate soils contain reduced iron sulfides that if oxidized, can cause significant environmental damage by releasing large amounts of acid and metals. This study examines metal and acid release as well as the microbial community capable of catalyzing metal sulfide oxidation after treating acid sulfate soil with calcium carbonate (CaCO<inf>3</inf>) or calcium hydroxide (Ca(OH)<inf>2</inf>). Leaching tests of acid sulfate soil samples were carried out in the laboratory. The pH of the leachate during the initial flushing with water lay between 3.8 and 4.4 suggesting that the jarosite/schwertmannite equilibrium controls the solution chemistry. However, the pH increased to circa 6 after treatment with CaCO<inf>3</inf> suspension and circa 12 after introducing Ca(OH)<inf>2</inf> solution. 16S rRNA gene sequences amplified from community DNA extracted from the untreated and both CaCO<inf>3</inf> and Ca(OH)<inf>2</inf> treated acid sulfate soils were most similar to bacteria (69.1% to 85.7%) and archaea (95.4% to 100%) previously identified from acid and metal contaminated environments. These species included a Thiomonas cuprina-like and an Acidocella-like bacteria as well as a Ferroplasma acidiphilum-like archeon. Although the CaCO<inf>3</inf> and Ca(OH)<inf>2</inf> treatments did not decrease the proportion of microorganisms capable of accelerating acid and metal release, the chemical effects of the treatments suggested their reduced activity. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.
Author Keywords: Acid; Acid sulfate soil; Acidophile; Metal; Molecular phylogeny
